docs.snippet: DWORKIN, Sylvia Raab passed away in her home in San Francisco on March 31st, after a courageous two-year battle with pancreatic cancer. She was 63. Born in New York and raised in Englewood, NJ, and Elkins Park, PA, Sylvia knew from her first trip ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
DWORKIN, Sylvia Raab

passed away in her home in San Francisco on March 31st, after a courageous two-year battle with pancreatic cancer. She was 63. Born in New York and raised in Englewood, NJ, and Elkins Park, PA, Sylvia knew from her first trip to California as a teenager that the Golden State was where she wanted to live, and in the 1970s not long after graduating from Hunter College she moved to San Francisco. Sylvia pursued pre-med studies at Mills College and began medical school at the University of Alabama before switching to business and obtaining an MBA there. Returning to California, she was the founding marketing director at the College of Professional Studies of the University of San Francisco. After marriage and the birth of her first daughter, she dedicated herself to her family and friends, and to community service, notably as President of the Hamlin School Parent Association and as a founder of the Friends of the Carol Frank Buck Breast Care Center at the University of California at San Francisco. Sylvia's true vocation, however, was practicing kindness; she was an extraordinary listener and friend, and had a rare gift for accepting people on their own terms. She is survived by her husband of 31 years, Peter Dworkin; her daughters, Kate and Meredith Dworkin; her mother Theodora Raab, sisters Jamie and Victoria Raab, and many friends who share in the sorrow of her passing. A celebration of her life is being planned for a future date. For information, write to sylviadworkinmemorial@ yahoo.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.

docs.snippet: WALDEN-- Dr. William D. Passed away on April 3rd sleeping peacefully at the age of 85 in New York City. At the age of 6, he met Elinor Klotz, who later became his beloved wife of 62 years. Bill graduated from NYU Medical School. As a board certifi...
docs.lead_paragraph: WALDEN-- Dr. William D. Passed away on April 3rd sleeping peacefully at the age of 85 in New York City. At the age of 6, he met Elinor Klotz, who later became his beloved wife of 62 years. Bill graduated from NYU Medical School. As a board certified OB/GYN at NY Presbyterian Hospital. Bill was one of the last solo practitioners who always sat through labor with his patients. His work was his passion. His patients adored him. During his career, he delivered over 5000 babies and, as he liked to say, "I never dropped one". Bill is survived by his wife Ellie, two children: Jonathan Walden (Sonya) and Elizabeth Corwin (Scott) and five grandchildren: Harrison, Zachary, Ryan, Amelia, and Sarah. Burial will be private. Please consider a donation in Bill's name directed to the Dawn Greene Hospice at Mary Manning Walsh Home

docs.snippet: UNGER-- Harold Milton, M.D. With gratitude for his extraordinary life, the family of Dr. Harold M. Unger, aka "PopPop", is saddened to announce his passing on April 2, 2015. Born in New York City to Nettie and Dr. Jonas Unger, he graduated from Co...
docs.lead_paragraph:
UNGER-- Harold Milton, M.D.

With gratitude for his extraordinary life, the family of Dr. Harold M. Unger, aka "PopPop", is saddened to announce his passing on April 2, 2015. Born in New York City to Nettie and Dr. Jonas Unger, he graduated from Columbia Physicians and Surgeons. Interned and completed his residency in New York at Mt. Sinai and New York Hospitals. Practiced surgery for 50 years at Mount Sinai Medical Center Miami Beach, FL. Pioneer in vascular surgery, early innovator of immediate reconstruction of breast cancer surgery and an early adopter of laparoscopic surgery. With wife Caryl ran Imagination Unlimited. Most devoted & beloved husband of Caryl Rose Unger for 68 years, also survived by sister Marilyn Glucksman, children Wendy Unger and Seth Schapira, Beverly and Stephen Unger MD, Laine and Arthur Unger, Nancy and Howie Unger-Fink, grandchildren Joshua Unger MD and Sarah-Hart Unger MD, Aaron Unger and Sophie Amieva-Unger, Rachel Unger and Michael Feldman, Seth Unger and Allison Jaffin, Samantha and Allen Katz, Sascha Unger, Jamie and Cara Unger-Fink, Nikki Unger-Fink and Ali Unger-Fink, great-grandchildren Margaux and Maelie Amieva-Unger, Jane and Georgia Unger, Max and Ellie Feldman, Annabel and Cameron Unger, and Elsie Bea Katz and a multitude of extended family. Donations can be made IN MEMORY OF HAROLD UNGER to Mount Sinai Med.Ctr. Foundation, Dept. of Surgery, 4300 Alton Rd, Ascher Bldg #100, Miami Beach FL 33140 or online msmc.convio.net/ donate_now and the UM Miller School of Med., Office of Med. Dev., 1500 NW 12th Ave- JNT- Suite 1020 East, Miami FL. 33101 Arrangements by Blasberg-Rubin-Zilbert (305) 865-2353

docs.lead_paragraph: MCGINTY--Captain James D. Age 94. Jim sailed with US Lines for 45 years. He served with USN-FAW1 from 1943-1946. A 1941 graduate of the NYMMA, he loved the sea and a good yarn. His daughter, Kathie and granddaughter, Gaia wish him fair skies. Memorial in May, Old Lyme, CT.

docs.snippet: GJERLOW--Bob, age 77, of Bedford, NY died Wednesday, April 1, 2015 in Redding, CT. Mr. Gjerlow was born on May 5, 1937 in Staten Island, NY. He is the son of the late Ragnar and Margaret Gjerlow. He enjoyed a long career in banking that included b...
docs.lead_paragraph: GJERLOW--Bob, age 77, of Bedford, NY died Wednesday, April 1, 2015 in Redding, CT. Mr. Gjerlow was born on May 5, 1937 in Staten Island, NY. He is the son of the late Ragnar and Margaret Gjerlow. He enjoyed a long career in banking that included being employed as a Senior Vice President for the Chase Manhattan Bank. In this capacity, Mr. Gjerlow ran the International Operations for the Bank in Tokyo and Singapore. Bob is survived by his wife: Nancy (nee Smith) Gjerlow; a daughter, Stephanie Gjerlow; a son, Robert Gjerlow Jr. and four grandchildren. Family will receive friends on Monday April 6 from 5:00-8:00pm at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah NY The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00am on Tuesday, April 7 at St. Patrick's Church, Route 22, Bedford Village, NY.

docs.snippet: NEPOMNYASHCHY-- Catharine. Ann Whitney Olin Professor of Russian Literature and Culture and Chair of the Barnard College Slavic Department, died on March 21. A native of New Jersey, Nepomnyashchy earned a B.A. in Russian Literature and French Lite...
docs.lead_paragraph:
NEPOMNYASHCHY--

Catharine. Ann Whitney Olin Professor of Russian Literature and Culture and Chair of the Barnard College Slavic Department, died on March 21. A native of New Jersey, Nepomnyashchy earned a B.A. in Russian Literature and French Literature and an M.A. in French Literature at Brown. She then pursued her Ph.D. in the Department of Slavic Languages at Columbia. She joined the faculty at Barnard College in 1987. Nepomnyashchy was the first woman to direct the Harriman Institute (2001-2009). She drew academics, writers, chiefs of state, ambassadors, public intellectuals, conceptual artists, dancers, and others to the Institute, and she broadened the geopolitical range to include Central Asia and Georgia and she made it a center of interdisciplinary inquiry. She was honored as the Institute's Alumna of the Year in 2012. Nepomnyashchy was on the Harriman Institute's Executive Committee and its National Advisory Council, and was affiliated with Barnard's Comparative Literature and Human Rights programs. She served as President of the American Association of Teachers of Slavic and East European Language (AATSEEL), as well as member of the Kennan Institute's Advisory Council and the Board of Directors of the American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies. She chaired the Executive Committee of the Slavic Division of the Modern Language Association. In 2011, she received AATSEEL's Award for Outstanding Service to the Profession. Cathy Nepomnyashchy was a masterful teacher and a curricular visionary. Her regular repertory included all periods of Russian literature and all forms of Russian culture, including popular culture. She collaborated in the classroom with colleagues in history, political science, and human rights. Her intellectual energy was a force of nature. She was an agent of change in the institutions and programs she served, the scholarly fields she pursued, and no less in the hearts and minds of the many people she knew. As a scholar, Cathy Nepomnyashchy's range was broad. She published on Pushkin, on great writers of the Soviet period, on emigre Russian writers, on women writers, on Jane Austen in Russia, on ballet, on popular culture and new media. She is known especially for her work on Abram Tertz (Andrei Sinyavsky): "Abram Tertz and the Poetics of Crime" (1995), and a translation with Slava Yastremski of Tertz's "Strolls with Pushkin." She coedited" Under the Skies of My Africa: Alexander Pushkin and Blackness," a volume that inspired an editorial by Henry Louis Gates, Jr. "Mapping the Feminine: Russian Women and Cultural Difference," another coedited volume, was a landmark in the study of writings by and about women. At the time of her death, Cathy was working on a book entitled? "Nabokov and His Enemies: Terms of Engagement." In each of her books she put a feature of Russian literary life into play in a way that expanded the horizons of her field. She is survived by her daughter Olga Nepomnyashchy, her mother Jo-Anne Theimer, and her brother and sister-in-law James Theimer and Sunnie Noellert. Cathy Nepomnyashchy was a brilliant scholar, thinker, teacher, mentor, and administrator. A memorial service will be held at Columbia University in the fall.
